headline: Trump Touts New Microsoft Data-Center Pledges After Local Backlash
summary: Microsoft has promised to pay higher utility bills for all of its U.S. data centers powering artificial-intelligence models, President Trump said Monday, accelerating plans by the tech industry and administration to respond to local fears that AI is pushing up electricity prices.  The software giant “will make major changes beginning this week to ensure that Americans don’t ‘pick up the tab’ for their power consumption,” Trump said on Truth Social.

The software giant “will make major changes beginning this week to ensure that Americans don’t ‘pick up the tab’ for their power consumption,” Trump said on Truth Social.

headline: Investors back energy providers over big tech for 2026 AI bets, says BlackRock
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, still believes in the investment case ​for artificial intelligence in the year ahead but ‌will be focusing on broader opportunities, it said on Tuesday.  Investors seeking ‌to play the AI theme into 2026 favour energy and infrastructure providers over Wall Street big tech, BlackRock said in its Investment Directions report, citing a recent investor ⁠survey it conducted.  AI and ‌big tech dominated markets and world equity returns in 2025, but as the multitrillion-dollar ‍race between the likes of Microsoft, Meta and Alphabet to build new data centres generates worries about uncertain returns on capital ​and higher borrowing, investors were looking for new ‌ideas, the BlackRock survey showed.

content.title: Investors back energy providers over big tech for 2026 AI bets, says BlackRock

AI and ‌big tech dominated markets and world equity returns in 2025, but as the multitrillion-dollar ‍race between the likes of Microsoft, Meta and Alphabet to build new data centres generates worries about uncertain returns on capital ​and higher borrowing, investors were looking for new ‌ideas, the BlackRock survey showed.

headline: Google to develop, manufacture high-end smartphones in Vietnam, Nikkei Asia says
summary: Google will start developing and manufacturing high-end smartphones ​in Vietnam this year, Nikkei ‌Asia reported on Tuesday, citing sources familiar with ‌the matter.  Google already has a large network of suppliers in Vietnam that assemble its products, including Pixel smartphones.  Google ⁠will begin new ‌product introductions (NPI) for its Pixel, Pixel Pro, and Pixel Fold ‍phones in Vietnam, with development of the lower-end Pixel A series remaining in ​China for now, the report said.

content.title: Google to develop, manufacture high-end smartphones in Vietnam, Nikkei Asia says
content.summary: Google will start developing and manufacturing high-end smartphones ​in Vietnam this year, Nikkei ‌Asia reported on Tuesday, citing sources familiar with ‌the matter.  Google already has a large network of suppliers in Vietnam that assemble its products, including Pixel smartphones.  Google ⁠will begin new ‌product introductions (NPI) for its Pixel, Pixel Pro, and Pixel Fold ‍phones in Vietnam, with development of the lower-end Pixel A series remaining in ​China for now, the report said.

headline: The trillion-dollar IPOs investors are watching for in 2026
summary: Listen and subscribe to Stocks In Translation on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, or wherever you find your favorite podcast.Investors are buzzing over potential $1 trillion tech IPOs in 2026, but which giants will come out on top? In this episode of Stocks in Translation, The Futurum Group Daniel Newman joins host Jared Blikre and Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Brooke DiPalma to discuss the potential $1 trillion IPOs of OpenAI and SpaceX. Newman breaks down investor hype, competitive moats, and market risks, while also exploring Google (GOOG) Gemini’s AI gains, Apple's (AAPL) innovation gap, and how Amazon (AMZN) and Meta (META) are positioned to dominate AI in 2026.Check out the full episode here. Twice a week, Stocks In Translation cuts through the market mayhem, noisy numbers and hyperbole to give you the information you need to make the right trade for your portfolio. You can find more episodes here, or watch on your favorite streaming service. This post was written by Lauren Pokedoff

headline: Tech Weekly: Apple and Google do a deal, Glasses for the Blind
summary:
STORY: From Apple and Google doing a deal to Glasses for the Blind, this is Tech Weekly.

:: Tech Weekly

Apple and Google-owner Alphabet have done a deal.

The iPhone maker will use Google's Gemini models for its revamped Siri coming later this year.

It deepens their alliance in the AI era and boosts Alphabet's position in the race against OpenAI.

Google's technology already drives much of Samsung's Galaxy AI.

But the Siri deal unlocks a massive market with Apple's base of more than two billion active devices.

And there's no sign Apple's dominance of global smartphones has let up.

The firm led the sector with a 20% share of the market last year - just ahead of Samsung.

Leading analyst Counterpoint Research said the firm saw solid demand in emerging and mid-sized markets.

And enjoyed strong sales of the iPhone 17 series.

The latest innovations in the tech sector were on show at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

.lumen showed off its so-called Glasses for the Blind.

The device goes on a person's head and acts in a similar way to a guide dog.

The firm said the glasses use haptics to help people with blindness go about daily life.

And employs AI to distinguish between safe and unsafe surfaces.

A new robotaxi design was unveiled in Vegas.

It's the product of a partnership between EV-maker Lucid, Uber and autonomous vehicle tech firm Nuro.

The car uses Nvidia's AI driving hardware, and can drive itself in certain conditions without a human using Nuro's autonomous tech.

David Salguero is Nuro's Head of Communications.

"We use an AI autonomy foundation model that basically learns as it goes along. So as we're driving, as we are testing, both on road and in simulations, it gets better and better at driving."

The group plans to launch robotaxi services in the San Francisco Bay Area later this year.

And AI wearables were on show in Vegas, too.

Some of the wearable tech included rings, jewelry, exoskeletons and glasses.

AI jewlery company Nirva showed products it claims can track your mood and record a journal of your day.

While tech firm ible demonstrated noise-cancelling headphones which they said can detect pollution and purify the air in front of your face.

The group plans to launch robotaxi services in the San Francisco Bay Area later this year.

AI jewlery company Nirva showed products it claims can track your mood and record a journal of your day.

While tech firm ible demonstrated noise-cancelling headphones which they said can detect pollution and purify the air in front of your face.

headline: Microsoft's Brad Smith pushes Big Tech to 'pay our way' for AI data centers amid rising opposition
summary: It won’t be easy for Big Tech companies to win the hearts and minds of Americans who are angered about massive artificial intelligence data centers sprouting up in their neighborhoods, straining electricity grids and drawing on local reservoirs.  Microsoft is trying anyway.  The software giant's president, Brad Smith, is meeting with federal lawmakers Tuesday to push forward an approach that calls for the industry, not taxpayers, to pay the full costs of the vast network of computing warehouses needed to power AI chatbots like ChatGPT, Google's Gemini and Microsoft's own Copilot.

content.title: Microsoft's Brad Smith pushes Big Tech to 'pay our way' for AI data centers amid rising opposition
content.summary: It won’t be easy for Big Tech companies to win the hearts and minds of Americans who are angered about massive artificial intelligence data centers sprouting up in their neighborhoods, straining electricity grids and drawing on local reservoirs.  Microsoft is trying anyway.  The software giant's president, Brad Smith, is meeting with federal lawmakers Tuesday to push forward an approach that calls for the industry, not taxpayers, to pay the full costs of the vast network of computing warehouses needed to power AI chatbots like ChatGPT, Google's Gemini and Microsoft's own Copilot.

thumbnail.caption: FILE - Microsoft President Brad Smith speaks before President Joe Biden delivers remarks on his "Investing in America agenda" at Gateway Technical College, May 8, 2024, in Sturtevant, Wis. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci, File)

headline: Bill Gates Says 'AI Will Change Society the Most'—Job Disruption Has Already Begun, 'Less Labor' Will Be Needed, And 5-Day Work Week May Disappear
summary: Bill Gates says he's still optimistic about the future—but this time, he brought disclaimers. In his latest annual The Year Ahead letter, published on GatesNotes last week, the Microsoft co-founder and philanthropist laid out what he calls "optimism with footnotes." headline: Apple Jumps on the Subscription Software Bandwagon. Why Adobe Stock Is Dropping.
summary: Starting Wednesday, users will be able to subscribe to the offering, dubbed  Apple  Creator Studio, for $12.99 a month or $129 a year, Apple said.  This first-of-its-kind subscription for Apple includes access to video, audio, and photo editing programs such as Final Cut Pro, Logic Pro, and Pixelmator Pro for a lower monthly payment than what each software previously cost individually.

This first-of-its-kind subscription for Apple includes access to video, audio, and photo editing programs such as Final Cut Pro, Logic Pro, and Pixelmator Pro for a lower monthly payment than what each software previously cost individually.
